instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT: What is PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT? PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT is a 0.75v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state .
definitions.PPVTTDDR_S3: What is PPVTTDDR_S3? PPVTTDDR_S3 is a 3.3v power rail that powers the DDR RAM when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state. .
definitions.PP1V5_S3RS0: What is PP1V5_S3RS0? PP1V5_S3RS0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PLT_RESET: What is PLT_RESET? PLT_RESET stands for platform reset. When this is asserted the machine will not POST. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 0v
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>

Old liquid spill
Green light, fan spins no display, no chime, usb lights up

<RESISTOR>R2805</RESISTOR> area has hole.
Replaced <RESISTOR>R2805</RESISTOR>. replaced <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> & y2805
Ran wires to connect broken traces.
Still does the same. Boo!


Check power rails
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL> 1,792
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3</SIGNAL> 1.499
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3RS0</SIGNAL> 1.499
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> 1.503
<SIGNAL>PPVTTDDR_S3</SIGNAL> 0.752

<SIGNAL>PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL> 0v Ah ha 

Diode mode to ground on <SIGNAL>PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL> 0.213v on donor 0.318 (significant ?)

<CHIP>U7300</CHIP>

pin1 0v
pin2 1.5v
pin3 0v
pin4 0v gnd
pin5 0.752
pin6 1.797
pin7 0v
pin8 1.495
pin 9 1.5
pin 11 1.9v
pin12  5v
pin13 1.5v
pin14 1.5v
pin15 6.4v (?)
pin16 3.2v
pin17 0v 
pin18 0.9v
pin19 0.03v
pin20 4.2v (odd ?)


<RESISTOR>R3210</RESISTOR>
pin1 <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> = 3.2v
pin2 <SIGNAL>MEMVTT_EN</SIGNAL>= 0v
<SIGNAL>MEM_RESET_L</SIGNAL> high


So i'm missing <SIGNAL>MEMVTT_EN</SIGNAL> which should come from <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> is high at pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R3210</RESISTOR> but 0v on the other side.
diode mode to ground on both side matches donor board (0.318 and 0.418v to gnd)

Replaced <RESISTOR>R3210</RESISTOR> even though measured fine, no change.
Replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q3250</TRANSISTOR> no change

<TRANSISTOR>Q3210</TRANSISTOR>

pin1  gnd
pin2 4.9v
pin3 4.9v
pin4 gnd
pin5 0v
pin6 0v

so <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is low when should be high.
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> seems to come from the CPU/PCH - is this the end for this board ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 0v
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET</SIGNAL> being low could have many causes. Corrosion under SMC/PCH, clock chip problems. It could be internal board damage if there really was a charred hole at <RESISTOR>R2805</RESISTOR> position.
